data.title: Kreider and van der Veen Named SUNY Scholar Athlete for Baseball and Women’s Tennis
data.meta_description: Albany, NY — The State University of New York (SUNY) named 13 student-athletes this past spring for their academic and athletic achievement hailing from Division
data.text:
Albany, NY — The State University of New York (SUNY) named 13 student-athletes this past spring for their academic and athletic achievement hailing from Division III SUNY institutions across the state with Hawks baseball junior Tommy Kreider and women's tennis junior Isabel van der Veen earning the SUNY Scholar Athlete Award for baseball and women's tennis, respectively.

The award was officially announced by the conference office Wednesday. The Spring SUNY Scholar Athlete Award recognizes student-athletes from SUNY colleges and universities sponsoring intercollegiate athletics at four and two-year levels who were named and voted upon by representatives of their respective institutions. Nominations included cumulative grade point average, current and career statistics, along with athletic and academic honors.

Both Kreider and van der Veen join fellow Hawks, men's basketball's Rylan Blondo, women's soccer's Rachel Eisert and field hockey's Hannah Ackerman who were selected this past year. Softball's Jackie Rometo and women's tennis' Onalee Batcheller were honorees for their respective sports in the spring of 2023.

Van der Veen battled through injuries to be a pivotal piece in her team's repeat championship run in 2024. She was named to her first, SUNYAC First-Team Singles and First-Team Doubles recognition after going 4-0 in conference play at third singles, while she and partner Batcheller went 6-0 in second doubles against the league throughout the year, while being honored on the All-SUNYAC Tournament team for the third time in her career.

"In as many years as I have been head coach of this program I have never had a student athlete who fully deserves this award as does Izzy," said Hawks women's tennis coach Rob Bruley. "Izzy is a true role model both on and off the court. A true leader and a student that others look up to. One of the most academically hard-working students a coach could wish for and one of the most coachable athletes I have ever had on the program.

"Izzy has played a major part in our continued success over the past three years," he continued. "An athlete who has been plagued with serious injuries, Izzy has just picked herself up, done her rehab and is always eager to get back on the court to help out the team. The adversity she has had to go through over the past three years has made her stronger and taught others not to take playing time for granted. I hope her senior year is injury free so we can all see the best of her on the tennis court."

Van der Veen has been a shining example of a well-rounded student-athlete, excelling in all aspects during her three years with the Hawks. She is a three-time SUNYAC Commissioner's Academic Honor Roll recipient, earned a spot on the Hawks Academic Honor Roll and Dean's List for six-straight semesters, and was enshrined into the Chi Alpha Sigma National Honor Society this past year, along with balancing her time honing her skills as a professional, working multiple internships including within the Athletic Communications Office.

"I'm amazed that she balances everything she takes on," Bruley said. "She thrives under pressure and gives 100 percent on the court, in the classroom and in her athletic department duties. A player who never misses practice and strives to be the best she can be every day. A true role model for any student."

Bruley boasts back-to-back recipients of the SUNY Scholar Athlete Award, as van der Veen's doubles partner Batcheller was named last spring following the captain's senior season when she led the team to a conference title, while also being named as the 2023 SUNYAC Scholar Athlete of the Year along with 2023 Women's Tennis SUNY Scholar Athlete honors.

"If ever a student-athlete deserved this award, Izzy is that athlete. She has been recognized by the conference on many occasions for her tennis abilities and it is fantastic to also be recognized for her academic accomplishments," Bruley added. "I'm very proud as her head coach that she has won this award and I only see great success for her as she graduates next year from New Paltz and moves into the workplace. This also has been a proud moment for me having back-to-back winners of this award following on from the conference recognizing Onalee Batcheller as last year's winner. Great academic recognition for our tennis program."

Kreider, meanwhile, enjoyed the best season ever for any individual who suited up for the SUNY New Paltz Baseball program. On the field, he set a new standard for individual success the team has ever seen, bringing home First-Team All-SUNYAC and All-Region honors, while becoming the first ever All-American selection, along with SUNYAC Tournament MVP after helping hoist the program's first ever SUNYAC title this past spring.

"Tommy has definitely maximized his success on and off the field this past season," Seay said. "He's consistently been one of our top students and it's great to see his efforts as a student are being recognized just as much as his success as an athlete. When you couple Tommy's on field success with his academic achievements he's very deserving of this honor. Like all of our players, Tommy does a tremendous job balancing his commitment to being a student while building this program."

As excellent as Kreider was on the diamond, he mirrored his success in the classroom. As an Accounting major, the New City, NY native was named as the 2024 SUNYAC Baseball Scholar Athlete of the Year after earning a spot on the SUNYAC Commissioner's Academic Honor Roll for third straight year, along with landing on the Hawks Academic Honor Roll and Dean's List for six consecutive semesters.

"Tommy definitely manages his time effectively; he's always taking advantage of road trips to get his work done. He has a strong grasp on his priorities and it's always gratifying to see a player's hard work and dedication be rewarded," Seay said. "I'm really excited for Tommy, not only for the success he's had this past season, but to see how he executes his plan for the 2025 season. I have no doubt he will come in prepared and hungry to lead a new crop of players."

Kreider and van der Veen were selected among nominees from 18 other NCAA Division III/USCAA Category schools including Alfred State, Brockport, Buffalo State, Canton, Cobleskill, Cortland, Delhi, Farmingdale, Fredonia, Geneseo, Maritime, Morrisville, Old Westbury, Oneonta, Oswego, Plattsburgh, Potsdam and SUNY Poly.

View the full list of Division III Spring SUNY Scholar Athlete Award winners below:

Division III

Baseball – Tommy Kreider, New Paltz

Kreider was an ABCA All-American (second team), ABCA All-Region III (first team), All-SUNYAC (first team) and the SUNYAC Tournament MVP in 2024. He led the team in every offensive category except RBI batting in the two-spot in the lineup. The Hawks won their first-ever SUNYAC championship title this season and advanced to the NCAA Division III tournament. Kreider is a junior accounting major maintaining a 3.77 overall GPA. He is on high honor roll and a Chi Alpha Sigma inductee.

Equestrian – Maggie Herbert, Morrisville

Herbert topped all riders in the high point rider competition across the year, finishing as the Regional High Point Rider Champion. At the Regional Championships, the senior was a double Regional Crown winner, taking home the title in the reining class alongside the open western horsemanship class. She followed with a third-place ride in open reining at the IHSA National Semifinals, earning a slot in the national championships in May, where she placed third overall in the NRHA/AQHA individual reining class. Herbert is a constant on the college's Dean's List with a 3.44 overall GPA and was a 2023 Chi Alpha Sigma inductee.

Men's Golf Co-SAOTY– Mackenzie Kim, Farmingdale State

In 2024, Kim was an All-Region selection for the second season in a row. He was also a Scholar All-American and four-time First Team All-Skyline Conference recipient. Kim's average score this season was 75.4 for the Rams team that placed 18th at the NCAA Championships. He graduated with a 3.74 overall GPA as a business management major.

Men's Golf Co-SAOTY – Adam Szlamczynski, SUNY Canton

Szlamczynski led the Roos in eight of the team's 11 events during the fall semester before graduating in December. He earned medalist honors at the Utica Fall Invitational, the Elmira College Fall Invitational and the SUNY Poly Invitational. Szlamczynski finished second at the VTSU Johnson Invitational, the Clarkson Invitational and the Oswego State Fall Invitational while placing third at the Nazareth Fall Invitational. Szlamczynski's round of 3-under par, 69, at the Clarkson Invitational will go down in the record books as it was the lowest in relation to par in school history. Szlamczynski was named the NAC Golfer of the Week on September 11th and 25th. He finished his academic career with a 3.93 cumulative GPA in the Homeland Security major and was named the 2023 SUNY Scholar Athlete of the Year for men's golf last spring.

Women's Golf – Claudia Winterberg, Cortland

Winterberg was First Team All-Northeast Women's Golf Conference (NWGC) with a third-place finish at the conference championship. During the combined fall/spring season, 14 of her 15 rounds were 85 or better, including four rounds below an 80. Winterberg tied for third at the Catholic (DC) Cardinal Spring Classic and tied for fourth at the St. Lawrence Invitational. She is a junior business economics major with a 3.81 overall GPA.

Men's Lacrosse – Trevor Bollinger, Geneseo

Recently, Bollinger was honored with the 2024 SUNYAC Dr. Sam Molnar award and was named the SUNYAC Men's Lacrosse Scholar Athlete of the Year. This award is nominated and voted on by the member institutions and is presented annually to a senior athlete with the best combination of academic and athletic ability with a minimum cumulative grade point average (GPA) of 3.30. Bollinger was the 2024 SUNYAC Defensive Player of the Year and a USILA Honorable Mention All-American. He helped lead a solid defensive unit for the Knights that held opponents to less than 10 goals per game. The Ithaca, N.Y. native led the team in caused turnovers with 30, and posted 50 ground balls. Bollinger helped lead Geneseo to back-to-back conference titles with a 20-10 win over Potsdam in the SUNYAC championship game, and was named to the All-Tournament team for his efforts. Bollinger graduated with a dual major in chemistry and sociology. He maintained a 4.0 GPA throughout his academic career at Geneseo.

Women's Lacrosse – Amanda Squillini, Cortland

Squillini was a 2024 USA Lacrosse Third Team All-America Defender, an IWLCA Honorable Mention All-American and an IWLCA Second Team All-Empire Region. This season she started all 20 games and was tied for first on the team with 26 caused turnovers and was second with 43 ground balls. Squillini helped lead a defense that allowed less than nine goals per game. In 95 career games, 94 as a starter, she ranks sixth in school history with 95 caused turnovers and also has 153 ground balls and 44 draw controls. Squillini maintained a 3.44 undergraduate GPA majoring in teaching students with disabilities and a 4.0 graduate GPA in physical education. She was recently named the 2024 SUNYAC Women's Lacrosse Scholar Athlete of the Year.

Men's Tennis – Alan Sabovic, Farmingdale State

Sabovic was the 2024 Skyline Conference Player of the Year and has been a four-time All-Skyline Conference selection (three first-team nods). He went undefeated at No. 1 singles flight with a school-record 16 victories for a Rams team that was the only NCAA Championship entrant to commence tournament play with an unblemished record. Sabovic had the second-best marks in school history with 40 career singles victories, an .851 winning percentage and 41 doubles wins while .794 doubles winning percentage ranks third. He graduated with a 3.74 overall GPA earning a degree in bioscience.

Women's Tennis – Isabel van der Veen, New Paltz

Van der Veen earned SUNYAC First-Team Singles and Doubles honors and was named to the All-Tournament Team in 2024. She was 4-0 in conference singles play playing at third singles and went 6-0 in doubles play at second doubles. She earned high honor roll and is a Chi Alpha Sigma National Society inductee. She is a junior business analytics major with a cumulative GPA of 3.81.

Softball – Janna Giliberti, Farmingdale State

Giliberti was the 2024 Skyline Player of the Year and named to the First Team NFCA and an All-Region selection. She was also named to the All-Skyline first team after totaling 61 hits and averaging .439 at bat with 48 runs, 24 extra-base hits and 26 stolen bases. She had an error-free year in the field as the right fielder. Giliberti ranks third all-time at Farmingdale State with a career .424 average, .630 slugging percentage and is second with 55 stolen bases. She graduated with a 3.87 overall GPA in applied psychology.

Men's Outdoor Track and Field – Isiah Brunache, Cortland

In 2024, Brunache qualified for the NCAA Division III outdoor track and field championship in the discus (18th place) and shot put (20th place). He was All-Niagara Region in the discus, shot put and hammer throw and All-AARTFC in the discus (4th place) and shot put (5th place). Brunache was the 2024 SUNYAC Championship Meet Most Valuable Performer after he scored 22 points at the meet with second place in shot put and hammer throw and third place in discus. He was also recently named the SUNYAC Men's Outdoor Track and Field Scholar Athlete of the Year. Brunache is a sophomore exercise science major maintaining a 3.98 overall GPA at Cortland.

Women's Outdoor Track and Field – Isabella Fabrizio, Oneonta

In 2024, senior Fabrizio was an outdoor NCAA Division III All-American Second Team athlete in the shot put. She placed 13th at the NCAA Division III championship meet with a program record of 13.76 meters. Fabrizio was the SUNYAC outdoor shot put champion at 13.67 meters. She was All-AARTFC and USTFCCCA All-Region in the shot put. Fabrizio placed in the top five in eight meets and won the shot put at the Cortland Red Dragon Open. Fabrizio graduated with a 3.76 overall GPA in exercise science and was named the SUNYAC Women's Outdoor Track and Field Scholar Athlete of the year and was a Chi Alpha Sigma National Honors Society inductee.

Women's At-Large – Lucy Ingro, Acrobatics & Tumbling, Buffalo State

Ingro was one of the best performers for Buffalo State as a top and as a tumbler in the inaugural season of competition for the Bengals. The sophomore was a First Team All-Tournament selection at the 2024 NCATA Division III Tournament. Ingro was also a crucial member of the first heat victory in program history in the duo tumbling pass, and holds multiple school records. In the classroom, the speech & language pathology major has a 3.93 cumulative GPA through four semesters, and was named to the NCATA Academic Honor Roll as well.

Learn more about the SUNY Scholar Athlete Award by clicking here.

Read the SUNYAC press release by clicking here.
